messages.message:
Here’s an updated version of the Facebook eng blog that describes the issue.

https://engineering.fb.com/2021/10/05/networking-traffic/outage-details/

The root cause that wasn’t mentioned in the blog or anywhere else is that there is a commandline tool that allowed an engineer to basically drain the entire facebook backbone with a single command instantaneously, with no confirmation prompt. This is actually not that uncommon of an issue. The engineer in this case expected a more interactive experience with the tool asking for confirmation of each region before draining, but instead, after issuing the command, everything went dead instantaneously, including removing the ability to reverse the change.

Reading this hurts my brain. What a mayhem it must have been. _Someone racing to a data center to reset things manually._

_When it rains, it pours._
Once they figured out the problem, the recovery was actually fairly straightforward.
To add a bit of Instabase color, a long ago (i think 2017), @Anant had clicked a wrong button on GKE which wiped out our production kubernetes cluster. :blush:
